title: Judah's Inheritance
shortSummary: Joshua 15 details the boundaries and cities allotted to the tribe of Judah as part of the Promised Land. It highlights the fulfillment of God's promise to give the Israelites their inheritance and records Caleb's faith and courage in claiming Hebron. The chapter also notes the ongoing presence of the Jebusites in Jerusalem, underscoring incomplete conquest.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Division of the Promised Land under Joshua's leadership

keyCharacters.name: Caleb
keyCharacters.description: A faithful spy and warrior who received Hebron as his inheritance and demonstrated boldness in driving out the Anakim.

keyCharacters.name: Othniel
keyCharacters.description: Caleb’s nephew who captured Kirjathsepher and married Caleb’s daughter Achsah.

keyCharacters.name: Achsah
keyCharacters.description: Daughter of Caleb who requested and received springs of water as a blessing for her inheritance.

keyCharacters.name: Children of Judah
keyCharacters.description: The tribe receiving their territorial inheritance, fulfilling God’s promise to Abraham’s descendants.

keyCharacters.name: Jebusites
keyCharacters.description: The inhabitants of Jerusalem whom the children of Judah could not drive out, remaining in the city.

definitions.definition: A race of giants descended from Anak, known for their formidable stature and strength.
Another name for the Dead Sea, a significant landmark defining the eastern border of Judah’s territory.
An ancient city also called Debir, notable as a conquest of Othniel.
The land allotted by God to each tribe of Israel as a fulfillment of His covenant promises.
A Canaanite people inhabiting Jerusalem before and during Israel’s conquest, not fully expelled by Judah.

outline.heading: Boundaries of Judah’s Territory
outline.description: This section describes in detail the geographic borders of the tribe of Judah, outlining its southern, eastern, northern, and western limits, emphasizing God’s precise provision of land.

outline.heading: Caleb’s Inheritance and Conquests
outline.description: Caleb receives Hebron and demonstrates faith by driving out the Anakim. His daughter Achsah’s request for water springs highlights the blessing of God’s provision.

outline.heading: Cities of Judah’s Territory
outline.description: A comprehensive list of cities and villages within Judah’s inheritance is given, showing the extent and richness of the land God allotted.

outline.heading: The Jebusites in Jerusalem
outline.description: The chapter closes by noting the children of Judah’s failure to drive out the Jebusites from Jerusalem, indicating incomplete obedience and conquest.

application: Trust in God’s promises and be courageous like Caleb to claim the blessings He has prepared for you.
Recognize that God’s provision is complete and precise; be thankful and steward well what He entrusts to you.
Understand that incomplete obedience can hinder God’s full blessing; pursue wholehearted commitment to God’s commands.
Pray for God’s guidance in claiming spiritual inheritance and overcoming obstacles in your Christian walk.

keyVerses.text: And unto Caleb the son of Jephunneh he gave a part among the children of Judah, according to the commandment of the LORD to Joshua, even the city of Arba the father of Anak, which city is Hebron.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights God’s faithfulness in granting Caleb his inheritance as a reward for his faith and obedience.

keyVerses.text: Who answered, Give me a blessing; for thou hast given me a south land; give me also springs of water. And he gave her the upper springs, and the nether springs.
keyVerses.significance: Achsah’s request teaches us to seek God’s abundant provision beyond the initial blessings.

keyVerses.text: As for the Jebusites the inhabitants of Jerusalem, the children of Judah could not drive them out: but the Jebusites dwell with the children of Judah at Jerusalem unto this day.
keyVerses.significance: This verse warns of the consequences of incomplete obedience and the challenges of spiritual compromise.
